p: MARV: One study reported that no viraemia or presence of MARV RNA could be detected in various tissues collected from R. aegyptiacus bats experimentally inoculated through oral or nasal routes [ 56], but subcutaneous and intraperitoneal inoculation resulted in high levels detected in plasma (10 3 to 10 4 TCID 50/mL) for five to nine days post inoculation, with titres up to 10 6.5 and 10 6. 0 TCID 50/g in the liver and spleen respectively. Virus was also occasionally detected in lung, heart, kidney and salivary glands with loads up to 10 5.6 TCID 50/g. Ranges for TCID 50/mL of MARV in tissues of naturally-infected R. aegyptiacus in Uganda have also been derived from a standard curve of diluted stock virus using Q-RT-PCR [ 74]. High values of 50,000–1,500,000 TCID 50/mL were obtained from liver, spleen and lung whilst values of 5–100 TCID 50/mL were obtained from multiple tissues including blood and intestines.
